Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Microbial responses to their environment are controlled by the molecular mechanisms that underpin the biology of the microbe. In addition, molecular biology informs our understanding of microbial virulence and its association with infection pathology. Molecular studies are informed by, and capable of improving, our use of therapeutic agents in the control of infectious disease. This module will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection (bacterial, viral, and fungal) as well as the impact of various therapeutic strategies of the molecular responses of infectious microbes. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods. Teaching material will be hosted in the University VLE to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to develop student knowledge and understanding of:

1. Molecular microbiology, focusing on bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

2. Therapeutic approaches to treating bacterial, viral, and fungal infections, including anti-microbial resistance, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products, and other strategies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Understanding how microorganisms interact with their host, and the environment, is fundamental for the understanding and developing treatment for microbial disease. On this module students will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection for bacteria, viruses and fungi. This knowledge will then be applied to help students gain insight of various therapeutic strategies used to control microbial infections and the challenges associated with this. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods to enhance student engagement. Teaching material will be hosted in the University virtual learning environment (VLE) to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Outline Syllabus
The module syllabus will cover the following topics:

● Introduction to the basic properties of bacteria, viruses, and fungi of medical, veterinary and ecological importance.

● Microbial genomes, structure, content, and replication.

● The life cycles of representative bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

● Understanding the scientific method for the study of microbial infection.

● Molecular mechanisms of microbial virulence, parasitism and host immune evasion related to disease.

● Microbial therapeutics, including antibiotics, anti-virals, anti-fungals, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products and horizon scanning for future molecular targets for disease control.

● Challenges associated with anti-microbial resistance, microbial evolution, drug resistance, horizontal gene transfer.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The module will utilise lectures and workshops, following short online study assignments. There will be 26 lectures and 4 workshops. Workshops will be linked to the four previous lectures, where students will be provided with pre-set work for discussion at the workshop to supplement learning and understanding of the content of the preceding lectures. with the view to enhancing student confidence and making the sessions inclusive.

Active-learning: Through pre-session online study assignments and workshops students will be provided a platform to synthesise and critically evaluate issues in greater depth. Students will be encouraged, in both in the classroom environment and in the VLE, to discuss the course content and online study assignments and share with each other their values and perspectives.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning tasks for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Online test, a mix of MCQs, MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total, split into two 45 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive.

Assessment 2: Online test, a mix of MCQs MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 60% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration.

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The utilisation of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. New programme due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Due to anticipate class size we have proposed online tests for this module. These will be a combination of MCQs, MAQs, Fill in the blanks (FiB), item matching and short answer questions. Questions will be carefully designed to assess knowledge, understanding, reasoning, evaluation and interpretation.

Molecular Microbiology and Therapeutics 2025-26

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 5
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS218
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programmes:Bioveterinary Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Microbiology and Infection BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Master of Biological Sciences MBiol 2024-25
Biochemistry BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biological Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Molecular Microbiology and Therapeutics
Short Title
Mol Micro & Ther
Module Code
BIOS218
Academic Year
2025-26
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus

15

Level 5

Neil Blake

Date of Approval
9 Jan 2024, 15:37
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
200
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
Microbial responses to their environment are controlled by the molecular mechanisms that underpin the biology of the microbe. In addition, molecular biology informs our understanding of microbial virulence and its association with infection pathology. Molecular studies are informed by, and capable of improving, our use of therapeutic agents in the control of infectious disease. This module will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection (bacterial, viral, and fungal) as well as the impact of various therapeutic strategies of the molecular responses of infectious microbes. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods. Teaching material will be hosted in the University VLE to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to develop student knowledge and understanding of:

1. Molecular microbiology, focusing on bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

2. Therapeutic approaches to treating bacterial, viral, and fungal infections, including anti-microbial resistance, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products, and other strategies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Understanding how microorganisms interact with their host, and the environment, is fundamental for the understanding and developing treatment for microbial disease. On this module students will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection for bacteria, viruses and fungi. This knowledge will then be applied to help students gain insight of various therapeutic strategies used to control microbial infections and the challenges associated with this. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods to enhance student engagement. Teaching material will be hosted in the University virtual learning environment (VLE) to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Outline Syllabus
The module syllabus will cover the following topics:

● Introduction to the basic properties of bacteria, viruses, and fungi of medical, veterinary and ecological importance.

● Microbial genomes, structure, content, and replication.

● The life cycles of representative bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

● Understanding the scientific method for the study of microbial infection.

● Molecular mechanisms of microbial virulence, parasitism and host immune evasion related to disease.

● Microbial therapeutics, including antibiotics, anti-virals, anti-fungals, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products and horizon scanning for future molecular targets for disease control.

● Challenges associated with anti-microbial resistance, microbial evolution, drug resistance, horizontal gene transfer.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The module will utilise lectures and workshops, following short online study assignments. There will be 26 lectures and 4 workshops. Workshops will be linked to the four previous lectures, where students will be provided with pre-set work for discussion at the workshop to supplement learning and understanding of the content of the preceding lectures. with the view to enhancing student confidence and making the sessions inclusive.

Active-learning: Through pre-session online study assignments and workshops students will be provided a platform to synthesise and critically evaluate issues in greater depth. Students will be encouraged, in both in the classroom environment and in the VLE, to discuss the course content and online study assignments and share with each other their values and perspectives.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning tasks for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Online test, a mix of MCQs, MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total, split into two 45 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive.

Assessment 2: Online test, a mix of MCQs MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 60% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration.

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The utilisation of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. New programme due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Due to anticipate class size we have proposed online tests for this module. These will be a combination of MCQs, MAQs, Fill in the blanks (FiB), item matching and short answer questions. Questions will be carefully designed to assess knowledge, understanding, reasoning, evaluation and interpretation.

 LO3 Examine the use of therapeutic tools to treat microbial infections.
 LO4 Appraise the principles of molecular microbiology, and apply this to solve problems.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Students will develop independent learning and self-evaluation skills.
 S2 Students will develop skills in reading, evaluating, and interpreting the scientific literature.

Molecular Microbiology and Therapeutics 2025-26

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 5
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS218
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2

Blurb
Overview
Microbial responses to their environment are controlled by the molecular mechanisms that underpin the biology of the microbe. In addition, molecular biology informs our understanding of microbial virulence and its association with infection pathology. Molecular studies are informed by, and capable of improving, our use of therapeutic agents in the control of infectious disease. This module will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection (bacterial, viral, and fungal) as well as the impact of various therapeutic strategies of the molecular responses of infectious microbes. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods. Teaching material will be hosted in the University VLE to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are to develop student knowledge and understanding of:

1. Molecular microbiology, focusing on bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

2. Therapeutic approaches to treating bacterial, viral, and fungal infections, including anti-microbial resistance, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products, and other strategies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Understanding how microorganisms interact with their host, and the environment, is fundamental for the understanding and developing treatment for microbial disease. On this module students will explore the molecular mechanisms that lead to microbial infection for bacteria, viruses and fungi. This knowledge will then be applied to help students gain insight of various therapeutic strategies used to control microbial infections and the challenges associated with this. The module will be delivered via lectures and workshops, utilising active-learning delivery methods to enhance student engagement. Teaching material will be hosted in the University virtual learning environment (VLE) to aid development of digital fluency and promote assimilation and appraisal of the module content. The module will be assessed by online tests combining MCQs, MAQs and short answer questions.
Outline Syllabus
The module syllabus will cover the following topics:

● Introduction to the basic properties of bacteria, viruses, and fungi of medical, veterinary and ecological importance.

● Microbial genomes, structure, content, and replication.

● The life cycles of representative bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

● Understanding the scientific method for the study of microbial infection.

● Molecular mechanisms of microbial virulence, parasitism and host immune evasion related to disease.

● Microbial therapeutics, including antibiotics, anti-virals, anti-fungals, vaccines, phage therapy, viral products and horizon scanning for future molecular targets for disease control.

● Challenges associated with anti-microbial resistance, microbial evolution, drug resistance, horizontal gene transfer.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The module will utilise lectures and workshops, following short online study assignments. There will be 26 lectures and 4 workshops. Workshops will be linked to the four previous lectures, where students will be provided with pre-set work for discussion at the workshop to supplement learning and understanding of the content of the preceding lectures. with the view to enhancing student confidence and making the sessions inclusive.

Active-learning: Through pre-session online study assignments and workshops students will be provided a platform to synthesise and critically evaluate issues in greater depth. Students will be encouraged, in both in the classroom environment and in the VLE, to discuss the course content and online study assignments and share with each other their values and perspectives.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning tasks for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Online test, a mix of MCQs, MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total, split into two 45 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive.

Assessment 2: Online test, a mix of MCQs MAQs, FiB, and Matching will be utilised to test differing learning styles, as well as data analysis questions. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 60% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration.

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The utilisation of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. New programme due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Due to anticipate class size we have proposed online tests for this module. These will be a combination of MCQs, MAQs, Fill in the blanks (FiB), item matching and short answer questions. Questions will be carefully designed to assess knowledge, understanding, reasoning, evaluation and interpretation.
